title: Homemade Apple Juice Recipes: Stovetop, Blender & Juicer

steps.title: Peel, core, and de-seed 3 red apples.
steps.content: Peel, core , and de-seed 3 red apples. Rinse off the apples with clean water before you peel off the skin and remove the core. [1] X Research source Try to remove all the seeds from the apple cores—although apple seeds aren’t deadly, they can make you sick if you eat too many. [2] X Research source Empire, McIntosh, Fuji, Gala, Pink Lady, and Red Delicious are all red apple varieties. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Put the apples, peels, and cores in a pot and cover them with water.
steps.content: Put the apples, peels, and cores in a pot and cover them with water. Pour about 5 c (1.2 L) of water over the peels, seedless cores, and apples, making sure that all of the fruit is submerged. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Simmer the apples for 30 minutes.
steps.content: Simmer the apples for 30 minutes. Wait for the apple-water mixture to reach a boil before turning the heat to low. After 30 minutes, check that the water has a golden tint from the apples. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Strain the juice and stir in ¼ cup (50 g) of white sugar.
steps.content: Strain the juice and stir in ¼ cup (50 g) of white sugar. Place a fine-mesh strainer over a bowl or pitcher and pour the liquid in. Then, add the sugar to the filtered juice. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Refrigerate the leftover juice for 2-3 days.
steps.content: Refrigerate the leftover juice for 2-3 days. Pour the leftover juice into an airtight container and try to enjoy it as soon as you reasonably can. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Wash, core, and chop 2-3 apples.
steps.content: Wash, core, and chop 2-3 apples. Core and cut up an equal amount of tart and sweet apples, removing all the seeds you can find as you go. If you prefer, peel the apples ahead of time (it doesn’t make much of a difference either way. [8] X Research source Apples like Granny Smith, McIntosh, and Pink Lady are on the tarter side, while Gala, Fuji, Honeycrisp, and Red Delicious are on the sweeter side. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Blend the apple pieces with 1⁄4 to 1⁄2 c (59 to 118 mL) of water.
steps.content: Blend the apple pieces with 1 ⁄ 4 to 1 ⁄ 2 c (59 to 118 mL) of water. Set your blender to the highest possible speed, if it has that option. Let the mixture blend for 1 minute until it’s smooth. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Strain the juice if you’d like.
steps.content: Strain the juice if you’d like. While the blended mixture is fine to drink on its own, pour it through a fine-mesh strainer into a bowl or pitcher if you’d like the beverage to be more like store-bought apple juice. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Store the juice in the fridge and enjoy it within 2-3 days.
steps.content: Store the juice in the fridge and enjoy it within 2-3 days. Transfer any leftover juice to an airtight container and stick it in the refrigerator. It will remain fresh for 2-3 days. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Core and chop up your apples before juicing them.
steps.content: Core and chop up your apples before juicing them . Remove the cores and seeds from your apples and chop them into smaller pieces. Then, stick them into your juicer and wait for them to be processed into juice. [13] X Research source It takes about 3 apples to get 1 c (240 mL) of juice, so bear that in mind when you’re juicing! [14] X Research source It can help to line the pulp basket of your juicer with a plastic bag before you get started. This makes it easier to use (or toss out) the pulp later on. [15] X Research source Aim to enjoy or refrigerate the fresh juice within 2-3 days. [16] X Research source
